#Text=Enhancing coral restoration practices in Seychelles: benefits and limitations of fishing lines and rope as coral stocking methods.
#Text=Charlotte Dale,�Athina Antoine,�Giovanni Strona,�Michael Bell,�Nirmal Shah,�Luca Saponari.

#Text=First published: 01 September 2024.\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14252\rAuthor contributions: LS, CD, NS designed research; LS, CD, AA conducted the experiments; CD, GS and MB analyzed the data; LS, CD, GS, MB, NS, wrote and edited manuscript.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Phanor H Montoya _Maya\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\rSHARE.
#Text=Abstract.
#Text=Coral restoration plays a pivotal role in mitigating the decline of coral reefs, increasing the need for implementing effective techniques and methodologies.

#Text=This study investigates the efficacy of stocking�Acropora muricata�and�Pocillopora grandis�using fishing line versus rope in mid _water floating nurseries, offering valuable insights for coral restoration practitioners.
#Text=Over 1 year, survival, tissue cover, growth, cleaning time, cost, preparation, and stocking timing for both methods were evaluated.

#Text=Fishing line reduced contact with fouling organisms, contributing to enhanced coral tissue cover and growth rates for�P. grandis�compared to rope, but no significant effect was detected for�A. muricata.
#Text=Survival differed among species, with higher rates for�P. grandis�compared to�A. muricata, indicating no impact due to stocking methods but species _specific differences.
#Text=Challenges like nursery collapses and amphipod outbreaks may have impacted survival, emphasizing the importance of consistent maintenance and accessibility of project sites.
#Text=Furthermore, the fishing line method reduced cleaning effort.
#Text=However, cost considerations and preparation complexities for fishing line warrant careful evaluation, particularly with regards to project budgets.
#Text=The study underscores the necessity for further research, incorporating diverse genotypes, species, and initial fragment sizes to refine restoration strategies.

#Text=In summary, this study provides important guidance for coral restoration practitioners, aiding informed decisions on stocking methods for different projects and species while considering the balance between coral health benefits and operational feasibility.
#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Rope reduces preparation and stocking time.
#Text=Costs are also much lower, presenting a good option for low _budget projects.\r* Fishing line reduces cleaning time and fouling impacts, offering growth and health benefits to reared fragments.

#Text=This technique is particularly interesting for established, well _funded projects with long nursery phases and/or high maintenance requirements.\r* Fishing line may be a good option where nurseries must be left unattended for long periods, especially for more sensitive species such as�Acropora muricata.\r* Fishing line stocking increases benefits with the increase of nursery rearing time and number of corals stocked.
#Text=Ropes degrade quicker, thus ideal for a single rearing cycle, fishing line is more durable and ideal for a broodstock concept.
#Text=Introduction.
#Text=Tropical coral reefs are among the most biodiverse ecosystems that provide socioeconomic benefits to local communities (Eddy et al�2021).

#Text=However, climate change is affecting coral health, causing more frequent events of mass mortality worldwide, endangering countries at risk from food insecurity, rising sea levels, increased frequency and severity of storms, and eroded shorelines (Good & Bahr�2021; Doorga et al�2023).
#Text=Small island nations, like Seychelles, face vulnerability due to oceanic resource dependence.
#Text=Coral cover decline has been severe (Bruno & Selig�2007), necessitating coral restoration to counteract degradation and preserve economic and social benefits (Etongo�2019; Edwards et al�2024).

#Text=In this context, coral restoration techniques are constantly adapted to suit the needs of specific environments, budgets, and capacity (Bostr�m _Einarsson et al�2020; Schmidt _Roach et al�2020).

#Text=Typical techniques are carried out in situ and rely on the  coral gardening   concept (Frias _Torres et al�2018; Bostr�m _Einarsson et al�2020), where coral fragments are grown in nurseries, such as mid _water floating ropes, prior to outplanting (Shaish et al�2008; Levy et al�2010).
#Text=All stages of restoration efforts face limitations, such as coral mortality during the nursery stage (Bostr�m _Einarsson et al�2020).
#Text=Therefore, adopting effective stocking methods is crucial to maintain coral health, growth, and survival (Levy et al�2010; Frias _Torres et al�2018).

#Text=Various factors can affect survival depending on the stocking methods used, including fouling organisms out _competing coral fragments, nursery collapses due to adverse weather, or unforeseen events like a pandemic, which can make nursery sites inaccessible (Montano et al�2022).

#Text=Consequences of these limitations include time _consuming tasks, such as cleaning and structural maintenance, which can cause project target delays, loss of colonies, and even entire nurseries (Frias _Torres et al�2018; Rinkevich�2019).
#Text=Therefore, selecting the appropriate stocking method is a critical aspect to improve the effectiveness of restoration actions.

#Text=Coral restoration projects utilize various stocking methods, including ropes and fishing lines with floating nurseries (Shafir et al�2010; Frias _Torres et al�2018; Coral Restoration Foundation).

#Text=Although the suspended stocking technique is considered advantageous over direct line attachment (Goergen et al�2017), there is limited information on the benefits and limitations of rope and fishing line attachment.
#Text=This study evaluated and discussed the performance and best practices of these two methods for two coral species in the Seychelles.
#Text=Methods.
#Text=Study Design.
#Text=The study was conducted on the northwest coast of Cousin Island Special Reserve in the Seychelles (Fig�1) from December 2021 to December 2022.
#Text=For the purpose of the experiment, a mid _water floating rope nursery measuring 10 m   6 m was constructed, following the design of Frias _Torres et al (2018).
#Text=Corals of opportunity were harvested from the donor site (Fig�1C) between 5 and 7 m.
#Text=Stocking was completed from 14 to 27 December 2021 (T0) with a total of 800 fragments suspended at 6 m depth in the nursery.
#Text=Figure 1\rMap showing location of the sites involved in the experiment: Seychelles (A), Cousin Island Special Reserve (B), donor and nursery sites (C).

#Text=Two methods of stocking were used in this study: one involved fitting fragments through a braided rope with 20 cm intervals, and the other used fishing lines (commonly found in Seychelles; further details in Table�1) threaded through rope at 20 cm intervals with copper crimps to create a loop for coral fragments (Fig�2B).

#Text=The two species of branching corals chosen were�Acropora muricata�and�Pocillopora grandis, which had been used in previous restoration projects and had proven resilient to fragmentation and stocking.
#Text=Table 1.
#Text=�Cost of materials used in experiment to compare two coral nursery stocking methods based on cost and currency change from 14 July 2022.
#Text=Costs were recorded once.

#Text=Materials\rSeychelles Rupee (SCR)/unit\rUnit\rUnit/nursery\rFishing Line\rRope\r\r\r\r\rSCR/rope\rSCR/nursery\rSCR/rope\rSCR/nursery\r1 m Sea King 4 mm Hemp Rope\r10.06\r12 m\r96 m\r120.7\r965.8\r120.7\r965.8\r1 m (1.00mm   200 m 53.00 kg) fishing line\r1.2\r15 m\r120 m\r18\r144\r0\r0\rCopper sleeves (1.2   0.5   0.3 cm crimps)\r2\r100 pcs\r800 pcs\r200\r1600\r0\r0\rCrimping tool\r140\r2 pcs\r2 pcs\r280\r280\r0\r0\rTotal costs (SCR)\r\r\r\r618.72\r2989.8\r120.7\r965.8\rTotal costs (USD)\r\r\r\r48.16\r232.7\r9.4\r75.2\r\rFigure 2\rImage showcasing stocking methods being tested in experiment,�Pocillopora grandis�stocked on rope (A) and fishing line (B).
#Text=Copper crimp acts as a barrier against algae on�P. grandis�(C) and�Acropora muricata�(D) fragments.

#Text=Four ropes, each comprising 50�A. muricata�fragments, were used to evaluate the traditional rope method (A. muricata�rope,�n = 200) and another four for the fishing line with crimping technique (A. muricata�fishing line and crimping,�n = 200).
#Text=�P. grandis�(n = 200) was stocked in the same manner.
#Text=After removing inconsistent observations, such as dead fragments at T1 and alive at T2, the final sample size was 799 fragments.
#Text=Data collection and nursery maintenance were conducted monthly (excluding weather _impacted months) until December 2022.
#Text=Alive corals were then successively outplanted in the neighboring reef around Cousin Island Special Reserve.
#Text=Data Collection and Analysis.
#Text=Six monitoring sessions (T1�T6) were conducted at different time intervals (39, 84, 115, 149, 181, and 333 days since stocking).
#Text=No monitoring occurred at stocking (T0) due to adverse weather lasting until T1.
#Text=The information gathered encompassed data on coral survival (including detachment), tissue cover, growth, cleaning, material costs, and preparation and stocking time.
#Text=All 799 fragments were evaluated for survivorship.
#Text=Fragments with any live tissue/polyps were deemed to be alive but otherwise dead.
#Text=A Cox proportional hazard analysis evaluated how survival over time differed by coral species and stocking method (Shahbaba�2012).
#Text=The model was implemented using the�coxph�procedure in the R survival package (Therneau�2022).
#Text=Data for this analysis consisted of  events   recorded for each coral fragment, the event being the survey on which the fragment was first recorded as dead.
#Text=Cumulative survival curves with 95% confidence intervals were calculated and visualized using the survfit function of the survival package.
#Text=Tissue cover of all coral fragments was also monitored.
#Text=A ranking scale out of 4, based on alive tissue cover (0 = dead; 1 � 50%; 2 � 50%; 3 = 100%) was used.
#Text=Tissue cover categories were treated as ordered categories.

#Text=The�polr�procedure in the R MASS package (Venables & Ripley�2002) was used to implement an ordered logistic model comparing tissue cover over time for each species between fishing line and rope stocking methods.
#Text=Results are expressed as the probability of a fragment falling into a certain category for each treatment.
#Text=Information on the presence of disease, predation,�Zanclea�spp., bleaching, and other general notes was also collected.

#Text=The hydrozoan�Zanclea�spp. was recorded since Montano et al (2017) reported lower susceptibility to corallivory and disease among corals hosting the hydrozoan compared to hydrozoan _free corals.
#Text=Additional notes were recorded on the presence of fouling organisms (e.g. sponges and algae).
#Text=Growth was recorded for a subsample of 30 fragments per treatment and species (120 in total), each considered a replicate.
#Text=The size of a colony was measured using its ecological volume (EV) with reference to Abdo et al (2020).

#Text=The formula below yields an approximation of the coral structures to the shape of a cylinder:\rwhere�r = (w + l)/4 and  h   represent the longest linear extension of three perpendicular measurements (h,�w, and�l), yielding a single value designating the volume of the cylinder occupied by each colony.
#Text=A Vernier caliper was used for measurements.
#Text=A repeated measures Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) evaluated growth in EV over time and compared whether stocking methods impacted growth rates in each species.
#Text=The ANOVA model was implemented using the�lme�procedure in the R nlme package (Pinheiro et al�2022), defining random intercept terms for individual fragments.
#Text=A�t�test was used to compare initial size (measured as longest linear axis) between treatments at T1 for the two species separately using the same subsample.
#Text=Costs and Timing Evaluation.
#Text=The study compared the costs of materials used for stocking coral fragments and preparing fishing lines and ropes, but excluded maintenance costs.
#Text=Experienced divers recorded the time taken to clean a single rope in minutes during calm days to minimize external effects.
#Text=Each rope served as a replicate, and cleaning was timed for structures in contact with corals, as algae growth near corals can cause partial or full mortality of the fragments.
#Text=In the fishing line method, the rope carrying the fishing line was part of the structure of the nursery, thus following a less frequent cleaning schedule.
#Text=Cleaning times were therefore recorded for these ropes solely as additional information.
#Text=With the rope method, the rope is the substratum in contact with the corals and thus suitable for algae to grow, potentially overgrowing the fragment.
#Text=A Welch two sample�t�test in R was used to compare cleaning times between stocking methods.
#Text=Preparation and stocking times were also recorded.
#Text=Preparation involved cutting the ropes, which was the same for both methods, and threading and crimping the fishing line into the rope for that method.
#Text=Stocking consisted of fitting coral fragments onto rope or fishing line and crimping.
#Text=These times were recorded by the person carrying out the activity and were considered supplementary data to explain the main findings or were a unique value.
#Text=All analyses were conducted using R Studio version 4.1.1 (R Studio Team�2020).
#Text=All results are reported as mean +/_ standard deviation, unless differently stated.
#Text=Results.
#Text=Survival.

#Text=Survival of coral fragments over time was significantly different (p < 0.0001; Table�S1; Fig�S1) between both species, with a survival at T6 of 95.7% for�Pocillopora grandis�and 54.4% for�Acropora muricata�(Table�S1).
#Text=No significant differences between rope and fishing line treatments within the same species were detected (Table�S1; Fig�S1).
#Text=Two fragments on the fishing line became detached during T1 and T3.
#Text=These were considered dead.
#Text=In addition, the nursery collapsed once during T4, severely affecting the survival and tissue cover of both species.

#Text=Tissue Cover\rStocking methods affected the tissue cover of�P. grandis�(Fig�3A) with fragments stocked on ropes exhibiting significantly lower tissue cover compared to fragments stocked on fishing line (p < 0.0001; Table�S2).
#Text=Tissue cover declined significantly over time (Fig�3B) regardless of the stocking method (p < 0.0001; Table�S2).

#Text=The interaction between stocking method and time was also significant (p < 0.05; Table�S2), indicating that the decrease in tissue cover over time was different between stocking methods, with lower tissue on ropes.

#Text=In�A. muricata, the effect of the stocking methods (Fig�3C) did not differ significantly (p > 0.5; Table�S3), although tissue cover declined significantly over time (p < 0.0001; Table�S3) regardless of the stocking method.
#Text=No significant interaction between stocking methods and time was found, suggesting that temporal decline in tissue cover did not differ between stocking methods (Fig�3D).
#Text=No fusions, entanglement, or damages from collisions were recorded, unless caused by collapses.
#Text=Figure 3\rComparison among the two treatments (A) and over time (B) of tissue cover of�Pocillopora grandis�and�Acropora muricata�(C and D, respectively).
#Text=Data from T5 is missing due to adverse weather conditions. 0 = dead, 1 = 100%, 2 = greater than 50%, and 3 = less than 50% of tissue cover.
#Text=Bars represent 95% CI.
#Text=Amphipods (around 80 individuals on a single fragment, Fig�S2) covering the ropes and fragments were observed and recorded.
#Text=In T1, 50�A. muricata�fragments on fishing line, and 199 on rope were found covered by amphipods.
#Text=One fragment was recorded for�P. grandison rope.
#Text=For T2, two fragments were noted for�A. muricata�on fishing line and 21 on rope, while eight were recorded on�P. grandis�for fishing line and 12 on rope for this time period.
#Text=In T3, the amphipods were only recorded on two�A. muricata�fragments on fishing line, with no further recording in T4�T6.
#Text=Neither fish scars,�Zanclea�spp., nor diseases or bleaching were recorded throughout the study, though dark unidentified spots were observed on four�P. grandis�fragments in T1 and T2 (Fig�S3).
#Text=These were no longer present at later dates.
#Text=Another unidentified discoloration was observed on two�P. grandis�fragments (rope 4, fragment 45, and rope 3, fragment 42) in T2 (Fig�S4).
#Text=These were yellow/white in appearance and disappeared in T3.
#Text=These also disappeared, and the fragments survived to the end of the experiment.
#Text=Growth\rGrowth of EV of�P. grandis�was significantly greater (p = 0.0033; Table�S4a) on fishing lines than ropes (Fig�4A).

#Text=For�A. muricata, no significant effect of treatment (Table�S4b) on growth is detected, although slightly higher EVs were estimated for the fishing line treatment for time periods T4 onwards (Fig�4B).
#Text=Treatment as a main effect in the linear mixed _effect model remains non _significant when the interaction term is removed (Table�S4b,�p = 0.3615).
#Text=Initial size (at T1) did not differ significantly between treatments (p = 0.053 for�P. grandis;�p = 0.15 for�A. muricata).
#Text=The initial size range, average, and standard deviation values are presented in Table�S5.

#Text=Figure 4\rPatterns of growth in ecological volume (EV) of�Pocillopora grandis�(A) and�Acropora muricata�(B) over time, estimated from a repeated measures (linear mixed _effect) model, comparing between rope and fishing line treatments.

#Text=Costs and Timing Evaluation\rThe total cost of installing four stocked ropes in a nursery using the fishing line and crimp method was US$232.7 and US$75.2 when using the traditional rope method (Table�1).
#Text=The cost to stock coral fragments using fishing line and copper crimps is 5.1 times more expensive per rope and 3.1 times more per nursery.
#Text=Average cleaning time for fishing line was 7.6 +/_ 4.0 and 16.5 +/_ 5.8 min for ropes.
#Text=Cleaning times were significantly shorter with fishing line (p < 0.0001; Table�S6), taking 8.9 min less on average than when cleaning ropes.
#Text=As additional information, the average cleaning time for solely the ropes holding the fishing line was 9.5 +/_ 6.7 min.
#Text=Times taken to cut ropes were the same for both fishing lines and traditional ropes (4 min), as methods remained identical.
#Text=Additional preparation times needed for the fishing line method were 41.5 +/_ 3.6 min, based on times taken for four ropes.
#Text=Stocking a rope the traditional way took 18.7 +/_ 4.3 min on average when stocking 50 fragments, while stocking the fishing line with fragments took 61.2 +/_ 5.2 min.
#Text=Results were based on times taken for eight ropes for each method.
#Text=Discussion.

#Text=Fishing line method, though more expensive, showed better results for cleaning times and�Pocillopora grandis�growth and tissue cover, while rope method was more cost _effective but faced higher cleaning time and lower survival for�Acropora muricata.
#Text=Survival rates for both methods when considering�P. grandis�were in accordance with other species of the same genus reported in literature (Schopmeyer et al�2017; Dehnert et al�2022a,�2022b).
#Text=Contrastingly, survival rates for�A. muricata�were lower for both methods (Howlett et al�2021; Dehnert et al�2022b).

#Text=Both species experienced a reduction in survival and tissue coverage due to nursery collapses, particularly during the south _east monsoon season, which limits accessibility and hinders timely repairs.
#Text=Full or partial collapses can occur when maintenance is reduced, leading to decreased coral survival, especially in exposed areas like Cousin Island (Montano et al�2022).

#Text=Furthermore, an outbreak of amphipods, which covered entire fragments, ropes, and fishing lines, particularly affected�A. muricata�during a specific time _window (T1�T3), suggesting a potential seasonal dependence.
#Text=Amphipods could affect their hosts by feeding on the tissue, as reported for soft corals by Caulier et al (2021).
#Text=Although the effects of the amphipod outbreaks on coral mortality are difficult to measure, it is speculated that their presence created damage to live coral tissue.
#Text=This phenomenon has not been previously reported for hard corals, and further studies are needed to understand its impact.

#Text=Nevertheless, corals on fishing line were reported to be less exposed to the outbreak, benefitting from the protection offered by this method, which could possibly reduce exposure also against predators and disease vectors.

#Text=Pocillopora grandis�generally displayed a higher rate of tissue cover than�A. muricata, indicating a greater ability to withstand stressors, including fragmentation, fouling organisms, and nursery collapse (Dehnert et al�2022a,�2022b).
#Text=Comparison of methods showed that corals stocked on fishing lines consistently exhibited higher tissue cover compared to those on ropes for�P. grandis.
#Text=Corals on ropes are exposed to fouling organisms on two sides, whereas fishing _line exposed corals only face them on one side.
#Text=Copper, used as an antifoulant, acts as a barrier and prevents algae and other organisms from coming into direct contact and competing with�P. grandis�and�A. muricata�(Dormon et al�1996).
#Text=The smaller settling area for algae and competitors on fishing line compared to rope results in faster covering of the material in contact with live tissue.
#Text=Thus, the fishing line method promotes higher tissue cover by reducing proximity to fouling organisms, which may also reduce exposure to predators and disease vectors.
#Text=Although copper is present in seawater, some researchers highlight its potential toxicity in the oceanic environment or to the coral itself (Blossom�2007).
#Text=This study did not investigate the effects of copper, but outplanted colonies have been observed growing around the copper crimp (C.
#Text=Dale, L.
#Text=Saponari).
#Text=Further research is needed to verify the effects of the copper crimp or other materials on coral colonies.

#Text=Pocillopora grandis's higher tissue cover with fishing line can have positive impacts on the outplanting process, which is important for the survival of healthier fragments on the reef (Reef Resilience Network�2022).

#Text=Significantly higher growth rates of�P. grandis�and slightly higher, although not significant, rates of�A. muricata�on fishing line may be attributed to the healthier status of corals, which induces them to invest energy in growth instead of competing with fouling organisms (Lapid & Chadwick�2006; Knoester et al�2019).
#Text=The use of fishing line also reduces cleaning times, as it is easier to clean than a thick rope with a rugged surface.
#Text=This is beneficial as 32% of project time is allocated to nursery maintenance, mainly in the form of cleaning (Nature Seychelles unpublished data).
#Text=With increased time availability, practitioners can dedicate more effort to other time _consuming activities such as outplanting, which is fundamental for effective results (Jacob�2021).
#Text=In contrast, preparation and stocking of fishing line was more time _consuming than ropes, as it requires more dexterity and precision to hold the fragments in place.
#Text=Similarly, the cost of materials used for fishing line was three times greater than for the rope method, making rope more economical.
#Text=Therefore, proper allocation of resources is an important task (Wear�2016; Bayraktarov et al�2019).

#Text=Despite frequent budget and logistics constraints on coral restoration projects, higher fishing line costs and slower preparation/stocking time might be offset if colonies are reared as donors (e.g.
#Text=Coral Restoration Foundation) due to high durability over time and reduced maintenance.
#Text=Acknowledgments.
#Text=The authors would like to thank Nature Seychelles, through whom this study was conducted, particularly S.
#Text=Ramkalawan and K.
#Text=Henri, who manage the reef restoration project, and our skipper J.
#Text=Aglae, as well as R.
#Text=Yathiraj, a former staff member.
#Text=We would like to thank the reviewers, who highly improved the manuscript, Dr.
#Text=R.
#Text=Klaus for the identification of the amphipods, and the Seychelles Ministry of Agriculture, Climate Change and Environment for the project support.

#Text=This study was conducted with funding to Nature Seychelles provided under the Coral Reef Restoration Project (PIMS 5736) by the Adaptation Fund through UNDP Mauritius and the Government of Seychelles.
